verses.sanskrit: evaṃ satatayuktā ye bhaktās tvāṃ paryupāsate | ye cāpy akṣaram avyaktaṃ teṣāṃ ke yogavittamāḥ ||
verses.transliteration: evaṃ satatayuktā ye bhaktās tvāṃ paryupāsate | ye cāpy akṣaram avyaktaṃ teṣāṃ ke yogavittamāḥ ||
verses.translation: Those devotees who, ever steadfast, worship You thus — and those who worship the imperishable, the unmanifest — which of these are the better knowers of Yoga?

word_breakdown.meaning: the best knowers of Yoga, most proficient in Yoga

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna’s question here is not mere intellectual curiosity — it is the sincere inquiry of a devoted heart. He has been worshipping Krishna in personal form, and now he hears of another path: the formless, the unmanifest Absolute. With a beautiful humility, he asks: “Am I on the right path?” This question has echoed in the hearts of seekers for millennia. The Lord’s answer, which comes in the very next verse, is one of the most reassuring words in all of scripture. Arjuna is really asking on behalf of all of us who love God with a personal, heartfelt devotion.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse articulates what is perhaps the central theological question of the Bhakti tradition: the relative merits of saguṇa upāsanā (worship of God with qualities and form) versus nirguṇa upāsanā (meditation on the formless Absolute, the akṣara Brahman). The Upanishads speak of both Brahman with attributes (saguṇa) and without (nirguṇa). Arjuna’s question reflects genuine perplexity about which path leads more directly to liberation. Krishna’s response in this chapter ultimately grounds both paths in the one Reality, while honoring the human need for a personal relationship with the Divine.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna is asking one of the profoundest questions in all metaphysics: Can the Infinite, the Unmanifest, be reached more surely through the manifest? The cosmic intelligence that sustains the universe is both personal and impersonal — it is both the formless ocean of consciousness and the personal wave that comes to greet the devotee. Those who worship the Cosmic Christ, the divine personality of God, are actually worshipping the same Reality as those who meditate on the formless Absolute. The question is which approach best suits the instrument — the human mind and heart.
commentary.goyandka: Here Arjuna poses the most significant question of this chapter: between the upāsakas of the saguṇa (personal, qualified) Brahman — those who worship the Lord with loving devotion as described earlier — and the upāsakas of the nirguṇa (impersonal, unqualified) akṣara Brahman, who are the greater yogis? The word satatayuktāḥ emphasizes unwavering, continuous union, while paryupāsate means to worship from all sides, completely. This is a comparison of two legitimate Vedic paths, and Arjuna rightly seeks the Lord’s definitive guidance on this matter.

verses.sanskrit: mayyāveśya mano ye māṃ nityayuktā upāsate | śraddhayā parayopetās te me yuktatamā matāḥ ||
verses.transliteration: mayyāveśya mano ye māṃ nityayuktā upāsate | śraddhayā parayopetās te me yuktatamā matāḥ ||
verses.translation: Those who fix their mind on Me, who worship Me, ever steadfast, endowed with supreme faith — these I consider the most perfect in Yoga.

word_breakdown.meaning: most perfect in Yoga, the highest yogis

commentary.dadaji: What a beautiful and direct answer! Krishna does not hesitate — He immediately affirms the path of personal devotion as the highest. The word yuktatamāḥ is superlative: the most united, the very best of yogis. Not merely good yogis, but the finest. What makes them so? Not extraordinary austerity or vast scholarship, but simple, supreme faith (śraddhayā parayā) combined with fixing the mind lovingly on the Lord. This is the entire science of devotion in one verse. God is saying: Come to Me as I am — your personal Lord — with a full heart, and you are at the summit of all yoga.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is a landmark declaration in the Gita’s teaching on yoga. Krishna resolves the question by pronouncing that the devotees of the personal form — those who engage in saguṇa upāsanā with total absorption (mayyāveśya manaḥ) and supreme faith — are the yuktatamāḥ, the supremely accomplished yogis. From the Vedantic perspective, this is possible because the personal Lord is none other than the Absolute with an accommodating face — the Absolute meeting the human mind on its own ground. Śraddhā here is not mere belief but a total existential trust that transforms one’s entire being.
commentary.yogananda: The supreme secret of Yoga is revealed here: immerse the mind in God. Mayyāveśya means to enter into, to submerge completely — as a wave disappears into the ocean. When the devotee’s mind is so saturated with the consciousness of the Lord that no room remains for lower thoughts, that devotee has achieved the highest yoga. Nityayuktāḥ — ever united — points to the continuity of this God-remembrance, not just in meditation periods but throughout the waking, dreaming, and deep-sleep states. Such unbroken God-consciousness is the mark of the most perfect yogi.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord’s answer is unequivocal: those who take refuge in the saguṇa Lord with complete absorption of the mind and supreme, unwavering faith are yuktatamāḥ — the most accomplished in yoga, superior even to the knowers of the nirguṇa Absolute. The term matāḥ (considered, declared) carries the weight of divine authority — this is not opinion but the Lord’s direct verdict. The three qualities specified — mind fixed in the Lord, ever-steadfast practice, and supreme faith — together constitute the full definition of the ideal bhakta. This verse is the very heart of Bhakti Yoga.

verses.sanskrit: ye tv akṣaram anirdeśyam avyaktaṃ paryupāsate | sarvatra gam acintyaṃ ca kūṭastham acalaṃ dhruvam ||
verses.transliteration: ye tv akṣaram anirdeśyam avyaktaṃ paryupāsate | sarvatra gam acintyaṃ ca kūṭastham acalaṃ dhruvam ||
verses.translation: But those who worship the imperishable, the indefinable, the unmanifest — the omnipresent, inconceivable, unchanging, immovable, eternal —

word_breakdown.meaning: the indefinable, that which cannot be pointed out or described
unchanging, immovable like an anvil, the basis of all

commentary.dadaji: Before telling us the outcome of this path, Krishna first describes the object of this meditation in glowing terms — seven magnificent attributes of the formless Absolute. Akṣara, anirdeśya, avyakta, sarvatraga, acintya, kūṭastha, acala, dhruva — each word is a jewel of philosophy. This is the nirguṇa Brahman of the Upanishads, the silent, boundless Awareness that underlies all existence. Krishna honors this path by describing its object so beautifully before noting the practical difficulty in the next verse. He does not disparage this path — He respects it while pointing to a more accessible way for most souls.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse presents a catalog of the classical attributes of nirguṇa Brahman as found throughout the Upanishads. Akṣara (the Imperishable) is the same term used in Kaṭha Upaniṣad; anirdeśyam echoes the neti neti (not this, not this) method of the Bṛihadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad. Sarvatraga (omnipresent) and kūṭastha (the immovable substratum) are terms from Vedantic analysis of consciousness. This verse forms the first half of a two-verse unit (completed in v.4), describing both the nature of the object worshipped (v.3) and the qualities of those who worship it (v.4).
commentary.yogananda: These seven attributes are not merely philosophical descriptions — each is a meditative experience. Anirdeśyam (the indefinable) is that vast silence the meditator touches when all verbal and conceptual frameworks dissolve. Acintyam (the inconceivable) is the cosmic consciousness that transcends the thinking mind entirely. Kūṭastha — the anvil, the unchanging ground — is the deepest experience of the Self as the still witness beneath all changing phenomena. For the advanced meditator, these words are not abstractions but lived realities of the inner world.
commentary.goyandka: This verse (continuing into v.4) describes the upāsakas of the akṣara Brahman — the formless, attributeless Absolute. The seven characteristics listed here — imperishable, indefinable, unmanifest, all-pervading, inconceivable, unchanging, and eternal — correspond precisely to the descriptions of the paramātman in the Upanishads and the Brahmasūtras. The word kūṭastha, literally standing at the peak or like an anvil, indicates the Absolute as the unchanging support of all modifications of name and form. These two verses together (3-4) comprise one complete thought that the Lord will then address in verse 5.

verses.sanskrit: sanniyamyendriyagrāmaṃ sarvatra samabuddhayaḥ | te prāpnuvanti mām eva sarvabhūtahite ratāḥ ||
verses.transliteration: sanniyamyendriyagrāmaṃ sarvatra samabuddhayaḥ | te prāpnuvanti mām eva sarvabhūtahite ratāḥ ||
verses.translation: Having restrained all the senses, even-minded everywhere, engaged in the welfare of all beings — they too attain Me.

word_breakdown.meaning: having completely restrained, having thoroughly controlled
the totality of the senses, all the sense organs
those with even-minded intellect, those of equanimous understanding
in the welfare of all beings, in the good of all creatures

commentary.dadaji: Here Krishna completes the portrait of the nirguṇa upāsaka with three defining qualities: complete sense control, equanimity everywhere, and joyful engagement in the welfare of all beings. The last quality — sarvabhūtahite ratāḥ — is particularly beautiful. It is not cold detachment but warm, universal compassion. The person who sees the one Self in all beings naturally delights in serving all. And the great reassurance is mām eva — they attain Me alone. Both roads lead to the same destination. The Lord of love is at the end of every genuine path walked with sincerity and complete surrender.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse completes the description of the nirguṇa path’s practitioner. Three essential qualifications are named: total sense restraint (sanniyamya indriyagrāmam), universal equanimity (sarvatra samabuddhayaḥ), and dedication to the welfare of all beings (sarvabhūtahite ratāḥ). The phrase mām eva (Me alone) is crucial — it asserts the non-difference between the personal Lord (Krishna) and the impersonal Absolute (akṣara Brahman). The devotee of the unmanifest ultimately arrives at the same Lord that the saguṇa bhakta worships. This is Krishna’s gracious declaration of unity underlying all valid paths.
commentary.yogananda: The three qualities named here are the fruit of successful nirguṇa meditation: mastery over the senses, which no longer scatter awareness outward; even-mindedness in pleasure and pain, gain and loss — the hallmark of the fully realized sage; and compassionate service to all, flowing naturally from the direct experience that all beings share one Life. They too attain Me — these words are an embrace. The great meditator who plunges into the formless Absolute does not find an impersonal void but the very heart of the personal God, whose love pervades all of existence.
commentary.goyandka: The conclusion of this two-verse passage (vv. 3-4) affirms that the nirguṇa upāsakas also reach the Lord — te prāpnuvanti mām eva. The word eva (alone, indeed) underscores that the destination is truly the Lord Himself, not some lesser attainment. The three qualities listed — sense restraint, equanimity, and universal benevolence — represent the ethical and contemplative foundation required for this difficult path. Sarvabhūtahite ratāḥ especially indicates that true jñāna is never indifferent to the world’s suffering; it overflows as universal compassion and service.

verses.sanskrit: kleśo’dhikataras teṣām avyaktāsaktacetasām | avyaktā hi gatir duḥkhaṃ dehavadbhir avāpyate ||
verses.transliteration: kleśo’dhikataras teṣām avyaktāsaktacetasām | avyaktā hi gatir duḥkhaṃ dehavadbhir avāpyate ||
verses.translation: The difficulty is greater for those whose minds are attached to the unmanifest, for the goal of the unmanifest is hard to attain by embodied beings.

word_breakdown.meaning: of those whose minds, of those whose consciousness
the goal, the path, the way
by embodied beings, by those who possess bodies

commentary.dadaji: This verse is a gem of compassionate realism. Krishna does not say the formless path is wrong or inferior in principle — He says it is harder for us, as we are right now, in bodies, with minds that naturally reach toward forms and faces. This is such an honest and tender teaching. The Gita never asks us to pretend we are something we are not. We are embodied beings — and for us, the easiest and most natural door to God is through a form we can love. This is why the tradition of the personal deity, the chosen form (iṣṭa-devatā), has been so precious to so many seekers throughout India’s long spiritual history.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is philosophically significant because it grounds the preference for saguṇa upāsanā in the inherent nature of embodied consciousness, not in any metaphysical superiority of the personal Absolute over the impersonal. The mind (cetaḥ) that has been shaped by a lifetime of sense experience finds it extraordinarily difficult to sustain meditation on that which has no form, no quality, no location. The Vedantic tradition acknowledges this explicitly — the unmanifest Brahman is the final station, but the mind typically needs a form-based stepping stone. As Śaṅkarācārya himself comments, the path of knowledge without devotion is immensely arduous.
commentary.yogananda: There is no criticism here, only an acknowledgment of spiritual physics. The mind is a mirror, and mirrors need something to reflect. To meditate on That which has no form, no attribute, no boundary — while the mind is still conditioned by years of sense attachment — is like trying to grasp empty space. The great jñānīs who succeed at this have typically spent years purifying and sharpening the mind through devotional practice first. The devotee who loves a personal form of God is not taking a lesser path; they are using the mind’s own nature as a vehicle rather than fighting against it.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord here gives the reason (hi = because) for His preference for saguṇa bhakti: avyaktā hi gatir duḥkham dehavadbhir avāpyate — the path of the unmanifest is, in truth, difficult for embodied souls to attain. The body and mind together constitute a field of constantly changing forms and qualities. To withdraw all attachment from this field and sustain contemplation on the utterly formless is a task of extreme difficulty requiring exceptional purity, discrimination, and dispassion. The Lord’s compassion is evident — He does not condemn either path but honestly acknowledges the relative ease and accessibility of the path of devoted worship.

verses.sanskrit: ye tu sarvāṇi karmāṇi mayi sannyasya matparāḥ | ananyenaiva yogena māṃ dhyāyanta upāsate ||
verses.transliteration: ye tu sarvāṇi karmāṇi mayi sannyasya matparāḥ | ananyenaiva yogena māṃ dhyāyanta upāsate ||
verses.translation: But those who, surrendering all actions to Me, regarding Me as the Supreme, worship Me with exclusive Yoga, meditating on Me —

word_breakdown.meaning: regarding Me as the Supreme, having Me as the highest

commentary.dadaji: This verse begins the greatest promise in the entire chapter. Krishna describes His ideal devotee with three glorious qualities: they have surrendered every single action to God (sarvāṇi karmāṇi mayi sannyasya), they hold God as the supreme value and purpose of their life (matparāḥ), and their Yoga is ananya — exclusive, undivided, without turning to any other. This word ananya is the key to the whole teaching. Not splitting the heart between God and a hundred other desires, but giving everything — all work, all love, all thought — to the Lord alone. This is the full blossoming of bhakti.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse (completing its thought in v.7) describes the archetype of the complete bhakta. Three elements define this devotee: karma-sannyāsa (the inner renunciation of the fruits and ownership of all actions, surrendering them to the Lord), matparatā (making God the supreme goal, the paramā gatiḥ), and ananya yoga (undivided devotion, the same quality Arjuna was exhorted to cultivate in Chapter 9 verse 22). The Vedantic reading here sees this as the path where jñāna, bhakti, and karma yoga converge — action performed without ego-ownership, with God as the sole aim and constant meditation as the accompanying practice.
commentary.yogananda: The phrase ananyenaiva yogena — through exclusive, undivided Yoga alone — points to a state of consciousness where the meditator has no secondary center of gravity. The ordinary mind divides its loyalty among many objects and goals. The ananya bhakta has collapsed all these into a single gravity — God. Every action becomes an offering (mayi sannyasya), every breath a remembrance, every heartbeat a prayer. The word māṃ dhyāyantaḥ — meditating on Me — indicates that even amid worldly activities, the inner awareness maintains an unbroken thread of God-consciousness. This is sahaja samādhi — the natural, effortless yoga of the devoted soul.
commentary.goyandka: Here the Lord describes the paramā bhakta (supreme devotee) through three definitive attributes. Sarvāṇi karmāṇi mayi sannyasya — renouncing all actions in the Lord — corresponds to the teaching of karma yoga (Chapter 5), where all fruits and agency are surrendered to the Supreme. Matparāḥ — having Me as the Highest — means the Lord is the sole ultimate aim, beyond all other pursuits. Ananyena yogena — through undivided Yoga — means exclusive, one-pointed devotion with no admixture of desire for other ends. Such a devotee meditates and worships as the very breath of their life.

verses.sanskrit: teṣām ahaṃ samuddhartā mṛtyusaṃsārasāgarāt | bhavāmi nacirāt pārtha mayy āveśitacetasām ||
verses.transliteration: teṣām ahaṃ samuddhartā mṛtyusaṃsārasāgarāt | bhavāmi nacirāt pārtha mayy āveśitacetasām ||
verses.translation: For those whose minds have entered into Me, O Partha, I become the savior from the ocean of death-bound existence — and that quickly.

word_breakdown.meaning: for them I, for those I
the savior, the deliverer, the one who lifts up completely
entered into Me, immersed in Me

commentary.dadaji: This is the most intimate and overwhelming promise in all of the Gita. The Lord says: I personally become your savior. Not just: You will eventually find liberation. But: I will lift you out of this ocean — and quickly. The word samuddhartā means to raise up completely, the way you would rescue someone drowning. Krishna is saying that for the devotee who has surrendered everything and whose consciousness has merged into His, He takes personal responsibility. This verse has moved saints to tears throughout history. It is God declaring His love and His commitment to every sincere soul who turns to Him completely.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse constitutes one of the most extraordinary divine promises in world religious literature. Ahaṃ samuddhartā — I, the Lord, become the deliverer — is a declaration of direct divine intervention for the complete devotee. The metaphor of saṃsāra as a sāgara (ocean) is ancient and profound: the ocean of becoming, ruled by mṛtyu (death), in which the unawakened jīva (individual soul) is swept about by the waves of karma. The grace of God, in this teaching, is not passive — it is actively rescuing, lifting the devotee completely out of the cycle. The qualifier nacirāt (quickly, without delay) makes this promise even more remarkable.
commentary.yogananda: Samuddhartā — the one who raises up completely. This word contains a universe of grace. When the devotee’s consciousness (cetaḥ) has truly entered into God (mayyāveśita), the laws of karma, of death and rebirth, no longer have the same grip. It is as though the drowning person has grabbed hold of a lifeguard who is infinitely stronger than the ocean. The ocean of death-bound existence is the great cosmic dream of separation from God — and Krishna promises that for those who have made Him the single center of their being, He will end that dream, and quickly. This is not a metaphor for some distant eschatological event; it can happen in this very lifetime.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is the culmination of Krishna’s teaching in this section and stands as one of the most profound assurances of divine grace in all scripture. Teṣām aham samuddhartā bhavāmi — For them I become the deliverer — emphasizes the Lord’s direct, personal role in the liberation of those whose minds are absorbed in Him. Mṛtyusaṃsārasāgara — the ocean of death-laden transmigration — evokes the enormity of what the Lord promises to overcome on the devotee’s behalf. Nacirāt (quickly) removes any sense that liberation is infinitely distant; for the true surrendered devotee, the Lord’s grace operates swiftly and decisively.

verses.sanskrit: mayy eva mana ādhatsva mayi buddhiṃ niveśaya | nivasiṣyasi mayy eva ata ūrdhvaṃ na saṃśayaḥ ||
verses.transliteration: mayy eva mana ādhatsva mayi buddhiṃ niveśaya | nivasiṣyasi mayy eva ata ūrdhvaṃ na saṃśayaḥ ||
verses.translation: Fix your mind on Me alone, and place your intellect in Me — you shall then live in Me alone. There is no doubt of this.

word_breakdown.meaning: you shall live, you shall dwell, you shall abide
there is no doubt, without any uncertainty

commentary.dadaji: This is the first rung of the great staircase of spiritual practice that Krishna now offers. The highest teaching: simply give Me your mind and your intelligence. Not just the mind — the intellect too, the buddhi that evaluates and decides. When both are placed fully in God, what remains? You dwell in Me — nivasiṣyasi mayi. This is not future tense in the ordinary sense; it is a certainty, sealed with na saṃśayaḥ — no doubt. These three words are among the most comforting in all of the Gita. God is saying: I guarantee this result. There is no doubt. Do this, and you will live in Me — permanently, from this moment onward.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse opens Krishna’s famous staircase of yoga (vv. 8-10), which descends from the highest to the most accessible practice. The first step — fixing both manas (the emotional, desiring mind) and buddhi (the discriminative intellect) on the Lord — is the practice of total surrender. The Vedantic tradition identifies manas and buddhi as the two primary instruments of the antaḥkaraṇa (inner organ of cognition). When both are consecrated to God, the entire inner life is transformed. Na saṃśayaḥ — not perhaps or most likely but without any doubt — carries the weight of absolute scriptural authority.
commentary.yogananda: Two instruments must be offered: the manas (the feeling-mind that desires and fears and imagines) and the buddhi (the rational intelligence that analyzes and decides). This is a complete surrender of the human personality to God. The ordinary person uses manas to desire sensory experiences and buddhi to figure out how to obtain them. The yogi reverses this entirely: manas yearns only for God, buddhi discriminates only in service of God-realization. When this transformation is complete — nivasiṣyasi mayi — you abide in Me. Not visit occasionally in meditation, but live permanently in divine consciousness. The promise is unconditional.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord now descends from the abstract to the practical, prescribing specific methods for those who aspire to the highest yoga. Verse 8 presents the summit: mayy ādhatsva manaḥ — place the mind in Me — and mayi buddhiṃ niveśaya — direct the intellect into Me. These two imperatives address the two primary facets of the inner instrument: the receiving, emotive manas and the discriminating buddhi. The result is stated as an absolute certainty: nivasiṣyasi mayi eva — you shall indeed dwell in Me. The word eva (alone, indeed) reinforces that the destination is complete identification with the Lord, not a partial or temporary state.

verses.sanskrit: atha cittaṃ samādhātuṃ na śaknoṣi mayi sthiram | abhyāsayogena tato mām icchāptum dhanäñjaya ||
verses.transliteration: atha cittaṃ samādhātuṃ na śaknoṣi mayi sthiram | abhyāsayogena tato mām icchāptum dhanäñjaya ||
verses.translation: If you are unable to fix your mind steadily on Me, then seek to reach Me through the Yoga of practice (abhyāsa), O Dhananjaya.

word_breakdown.meaning: to fix, to concentrate, to place in samādhi
you are not able, you cannot
seek to attain, desire to reach

commentary.dadaji: The Gita meets us exactly where we are. If the highest — total, unwavering God-absorption — is beyond you right now, do not despair. Come down one step: take up abhyāsa, the practice of steady repetition. What is abhyāsa? It is the daily, patient, persistent effort to bring the mind back to God whenever it wanders. Mantra japa, meditation, reading scripture, singing God’s names — these are all abhyāsa. The word icchāptum is beautiful: aspire to reach Me. Even the aspiration counts. You do not need to have achieved it — just keep trying, keep turning back toward God. The very effort is itself a form of devotion.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse introduces abhyāsa yoga — the yoga of sustained spiritual practice — as the second rung of the staircase. Abhyāsa was defined precisely in Chapter 6 (vv. 35-36): it is the practice of repeatedly bringing the wandering mind back to the object of meditation. The Yoga Sūtras of Patañjali also identify abhyāsa (practice) and vairāgya (dispassion) as the two foundational pillars of yoga. Krishna’s use of icchāptum (aspire to attain) is significant — even the aspiration itself, the sincere desire for God, constitutes a form of practice and draws the Lord’s grace. The name dhanäñjaya (conqueror of wealth) is perhaps chosen here to remind Arjuna that spiritual attainment requires the same energy as conquest.
commentary.yogananda: Abhyāsa yoga is the science of spiritual habit-formation. The mind that cannot yet sustain God-consciousness spontaneously must be trained through daily, disciplined practice until God-remembrance becomes as natural as breathing. Every great mystic has walked this path: rising before dawn for meditation, returning the mind to the divine presence hundreds of times a day, chanting, praying, studying scripture — all of this is abhyāsa. The word sthiram (steadily, without wavering) points to the quality of attention that practice develops: not a flickering, distracted awareness, but a steady, single-pointed contemplative gaze directed at the Divine.
commentary.goyandka: In verse 9, the Lord graciously provides for those who cannot immediately achieve the perfection described in verse 8. For them, the prescription is abhyāsayoga — the yoga of regular, disciplined practice. Abhyāsa, as discussed in Chapter 6, means the repeated effort to withdraw the mind from distractions and fix it on the chosen object of meditation. The Lord does not say you must succeed but mām icchāptum — aspire, desire, seek to attain Me. The very sincere aspiration, sustained through regular practice, is itself a powerful sādhana. The word dhanäñjaya here may carry the implication: you who have conquered enemies — now conquer the mind through this practice.

verses.sanskrit: abhyāse’py asamartho’si matkarmaparamo bhava | madartham api karmāṇi kurvan siddhim avāpsyasi ||
verses.transliteration: abhyāse’py asamartho’si matkarmaparamo bhava | madartham api karmāṇi kurvan siddhim avāpsyasi ||
verses.translation: If you are also incapable of abhyāsa (practice), then let performing actions for My sake be your supreme aim — even by performing actions for My sake, you shall attain perfection.

word_breakdown.meaning: even in practice, even in abhyāsa
one whose supreme aim is action for Me (mat=My, karma=action, parama=supreme)
for My sake, for My purpose
you shall attain, you shall obtain

commentary.dadaji: And now the bottom rung of the ladder — and what a beautiful rung it is. If you cannot meditate and cannot even sustain regular practice, then simply do everything as an offering to God. Cook for God, work for God, serve others as if serving God, raise your children for God. This is karma yoga refined to its purest essence. The word matkarmaparamaḥ — one whose supreme aim is My work — does not mean doing great religious projects. It means that in whatever you do — however small or ordinary — God is your reason, your audience, your dedication. And the promise is the same: siddhim avāpsyasi — you shall attain perfection. All three rungs lead to the same summit.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The third rung of the staircase completes the descent to meet the seeker wherever they are. If neither fixed meditation (v.8) nor systematic practice (v.9) is yet possible, the Lord prescribes matkarmaparatā — making all one’s actions supremely for God’s sake. This is essentially the karma yoga of Chapter 3 now infused with the spirit of Bhakti. Madartham karmāṇi kurvan — performing actions for My sake — transforms every worldly activity into worship. The promise is siddhim avāpsyasi — perfection shall be attained. This verse represents the Gita’s democratic spirituality at its finest: no one is excluded, no one is too spiritually immature to begin the journey.
commentary.yogananda: This is perhaps the most universally accessible spiritual teaching in the Gita. You do not need to be a great meditator, or even a consistent practitioner. Begin where you are. Take your work, your family duties, your creative gifts, your service to society — and offer them all to God as a sacred act. Madartham — for My sake — is the transforming intention. The same physical action becomes entirely different in quality when performed as an offering to God rather than for personal gain or ego satisfaction. This shift of intention, sustained over time, purifies the heart and gradually opens it to deeper meditation, to consistent practice, and finally to the full God-absorption of verse 8.
commentary.goyandka: This verse represents the Lord’s supreme condescension and grace — meeting the devotee at whatever level they currently stand. For those who cannot yet engage in formal meditation (v.8) or systematic repetitive practice (v.9), the third path is karma offered to God: matkarmaparamo bhava — let actions for My sake be your highest aim. The compound matkarmaparama indicates a person whose inner hierarchy of values places action in God’s service at the absolute top. Even such a person — engaged in the world but with God as the supreme goal — shall attain siddhim, the fullness of spiritual perfection. This is the most accessible entry point of the Gita’s entire yoga, and its promise is identical to the highest path.
